title: Acts Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 15.

questions.question: What did certain men from Judaea teach about salvation in Acts 15:1?
options: Except ye be circumcised after the manner of Moses, ye cannot be saved
Faith alone is sufficient for salvation
Baptism is necessary for salvation
Keeping the Ten Commandments is required for salvation
questions.correctAnswer: Except ye be circumcised after the manner of Moses, ye cannot be saved
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1 states that certain men taught the brethren that except they be circumcised after the manner of Moses, they could not be saved.

questions.question: Who went up to Jerusalem to discuss the question of circumcision according to Acts 15:2?
options: Paul and Barnabas
Peter and John
James and Silas
Stephen and Philip
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas
questions.explanation: Acts 15:2 states that Paul and Barnabas, along with certain others, were sent to Jerusalem to consult the apostles and elders about the matter.

questions.question: What places did Paul and Barnabas pass through on their way to Jerusalem as described in Acts 15:3?
options: Phenice and Samaria
Jericho and Bethlehem
Damascus and Antioch
Tarsus and Cyprus
questions.correctAnswer: Phenice and Samaria
questions.explanation: Acts 15:3 explains that they passed through Phenice and Samaria, declaring the conversion of the Gentiles.

questions.question: Who rose up and spoke after much disputing in Acts 15:7?
options: Peter
James
Paul
Barnabas
questions.correctAnswer: Peter
questions.explanation: Acts 15:7 states that Peter stood up and addressed the assembly after much disputing among the apostles and elders.

questions.question: According to Acts 15:9, what did God do to the hearts of the Gentiles by faith?
options: Purified their hearts
Circumcised their hearts
Judged their hearts
Hardened their hearts
questions.correctAnswer: Purified their hearts
questions.explanation: Acts 15:9 explains that God purified the hearts of the Gentiles by faith, putting no difference between them and the Jews.

questions.question: What did James say should be written to the Gentiles in Acts 15:20?
options: That they abstain from pollutions of idols, from fornication, from things strangled, and from blood
That they must be circumcised and keep the law of Moses
That they should fast twice a week
That they should attend synagogue every Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: That they abstain from pollutions of idols, from fornication, from things strangled, and from blood
questions.explanation: Acts 15:20 records James' judgment that Gentile believers should abstain from these specific things.

questions.question: Who were sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch according to Acts 15:22?
options: Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas
Peter and John
Stephen and Philip
James and Apollos
questions.correctAnswer: Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas
questions.explanation: Acts 15:22 tells that Judas Barsabas and Silas, who were leaders among the brethren, were sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch.

questions.question: What reason was given in the letter sent to the Gentiles about circumcision in Acts 15:24?
options: The apostles gave no such commandment to be circumcised
Circumcision was required for salvation
Only the Jews must be circumcised
Circumcision was optional for Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: The apostles gave no such commandment to be circumcised
questions.explanation: Acts 15:24 states that the apostles did not command Gentiles to be circumcised, refuting the false teachers.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Acts 15:29: 'That ye abstain from meats offered to idols, and from blood, and from things strangled, and from ______.'
options: fornication
stealing
lying
idolatry
questions.correctAnswer: fornication
questions.explanation: Acts 15:29 instructs to abstain from fornication along with meats offered to idols, blood, and things strangled.

questions.question: True or False: According to Acts 15:31, the brethren rejoiced after reading the letter sent to Antioch.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 15:31 clearly states that when the letter was read in Antioch, the brethren rejoiced for the consolation.

questions.question: True or False: Silas left Antioch immediately after delivering the letter according to Acts 15:33-34.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 15:34 states that Silas chose to remain in Antioch even after Judas and Silas were dismissed.

questions.question: Who did Barnabas want to take with him on the second journey according to Acts 15:37?
options: John, whose surname was Mark
Silas
Timothy
Luke
questions.correctAnswer: John, whose surname was Mark
questions.explanation: Acts 15:37 states that Barnabas wanted to take John, called Mark, with them on the journey.

questions.question: Why did Paul not want to take John Mark with them according to Acts 15:38?
options: Because he departed from them in Pamphylia and did not continue with them in the work
Because John Mark was too young
Because John Mark was sick
Because John Mark wanted to stay in Antioch
questions.correctAnswer: Because he departed from them in Pamphylia and did not continue with them in the work
questions.explanation: Acts 15:38 explains Paul did not think it good to take John Mark because he had left them previously in Pamphylia and did not continue with the work.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the disagreement between Paul and Barnabas in Acts 15:39?
options: They parted ways; Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus
They decided to go together with Mark
They asked the apostles to decide
They postponed the journey
questions.correctAnswer: They parted ways; Barnabas took Mark and sailed to Cyprus
questions.explanation: Acts 15:39 states the contention was so sharp that they separated, with Barnabas taking Mark and sailing to Cyprus.

questions.question: True or False: Paul chose Silas and was recommended by the brethren to the grace of God as per Acts 15:40.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 15:40 confirms that Paul chose Silas and was recommended by the brethren to the grace of God.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is confused about whether they must be circumcised to be saved. Based on Acts 15, what biblical truth would you share regarding salvation and faith?
options: Salvation comes through faith in Jesus Christ by grace, not by circumcision or law keeping.
Circumcision is mandatory for all believers to be saved.
Faith alone is not enough; strict observance of the law is necessary.
Only Gentiles need to be circumcised to be saved.
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation comes through faith in Jesus Christ by grace, not by circumcision or law keeping.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1-11 explains the dispute about circumcision, and Peter and James clarify that salvation is by grace through faith in Jesus Christ, not by the law or circumcision.

questions.question: How does Acts 15 teach about the importance of unity and seeking counsel within the church when facing a theological dispute?
options: The apostles and elders gathered to consider the matter together before deciding.
Paul and Barnabas decided alone without consulting others.
The dispute was ignored to avoid conflict.
Each church made its own independent decision without consultation.
questions.correctAnswer: The apostles and elders gathered to consider the matter together before deciding.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:6 shows that the apostles and elders came together to deliberate, emphasizing the value of collective discernment and unity in the church.

questions.question: What practical lesson about trusting God's guidance can we learn from the decision made by the apostles and elders in Acts 15?
options: They relied on the Holy Spirit's guidance to avoid placing unnecessary burdens on believers.
They made decisions based on popular opinion rather than spiritual discernment.
They enforced strict adherence to the Mosaic law on all believers.
They postponed the decision indefinitely.
questions.correctAnswer: They relied on the Holy Spirit's guidance to avoid placing unnecessary burdens on believers.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:28 says it seemed good to the Holy Ghost and the apostles to lay no greater burden on Gentile believers, showing reliance on the Spirit's leading for practical church decisions.

questions.question: How does Acts 15 instruct believers to live in holiness and avoid temptation in practical daily life?
options: By abstaining from food offered to idols, blood, strangled animals, and sexual immorality.
By following all Jewish ceremonial laws strictly.
By avoiding fellowship with Gentiles entirely.
By focusing only on faith and ignoring lifestyle choices.
questions.correctAnswer: By abstaining from food offered to idols, blood, strangled animals, and sexual immorality.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:20 and 15:29 list specific behaviors to abstain from, emphasizing holiness and obedience as practical ways to live faithfully.

questions.question: A believer is struggling to understand how God views Gentile converts. What assurance does Acts 15 offer about God's acceptance of all believers?
options: God purifies the hearts of Gentiles by faith, making no distinction between Jews and Gentiles.
Gentiles must first become Jews to be accepted.
Only circumcised believers are truly accepted by God.
Gentile believers are second-class members in the church.
questions.correctAnswer: God purifies the hearts of Gentiles by faith, making no distinction between Jews and Gentiles.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:8-9 explains that God gave the Holy Spirit to Gentiles and purified their hearts by faith, showing equal acceptance.

questions.question: According to Acts 15, how should a believer respond when faced with unnecessary burdens or rules beyond God's commands?
options: They should trust that God does not desire to burden His followers beyond what is necessary.
They must obey all traditions without question.
They should reject the church leadership.
They should create their own rules to follow.
questions.correctAnswer: They should trust that God does not desire to burden His followers beyond what is necessary.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:28-29 shows that the apostles, led by the Holy Spirit, imposed only necessary requirements, teaching believers to avoid unnecessary burdens.

questions.question: True or False: Acts 15 shows that God’s work among the Gentiles was unexpected by the early church leaders.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 15:14-17 shows James citing prophecy and recognizing God’s plan to include Gentiles, indicating the work was expected and part of God's purpose.

questions.question: How does Acts 15 demonstrate the role of fellowship and encouragement among believers during times of doctrinal uncertainty?
options: Judas and Silas, as prophets, exhorted and encouraged the brethren with many words.
The church ignored the issue and ceased fellowship.
Paul and Barnabas refused to communicate with others.
Believers were left to struggle alone.
questions.correctAnswer: Judas and Silas, as prophets, exhorted and encouraged the brethren with many words.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:32 shows how prophets Judas and Silas strengthened and encouraged believers, highlighting the importance of supportive fellowship.

questions.question: When Paul and Barnabas disagreed about taking John Mark on their journey, what biblical principle about handling disagreements can we learn from Acts 15?
options: Even faithful servants can have sharp disagreements, but it is important to continue the work of the Lord.
Disagreements should end ministry work immediately.
Disputes among believers always lead to division and failure.
One must always follow the majority opinion.
questions.correctAnswer: Even faithful servants can have sharp disagreements, but it is important to continue the work of the Lord.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:36-41 records a sharp contention, yet both Paul and Barnabas continued ministry separately, demonstrating perseverance despite conflict.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Acts 15 teaches that the apostles sent letters to Gentile believers to encourage them to abstain from ______, _______, things strangled, and blood.
options: meats offered to idols, fornication
wine, gossip
circumcision, fasting
prayer, almsgiving
questions.correctAnswer: meats offered to idols, fornication
questions.explanation: Acts 15:20 and 15:29 instruct Gentile believers to abstain from meats offered to idols and fornication, along with other practices, to live holy lives.

questions.question: What does Acts 15 teach about the importance of sharing testimonies and declaring God’s works among believers?
options: Paul and Barnabas declared all God had done, causing great joy among believers.
Testimonies are unnecessary and distracting.
Only written scripture is important, not personal testimonies.
Believers should keep their experiences private.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas declared all God had done, causing great joy among believers.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:3-4 shows Paul and Barnabas sharing news about Gentile conversions, which brought joy and encouragement to the church.

questions.question: How does Acts 15 model the practice of church leadership involving multiple representatives for important decisions?
options: Chosen men including Judas Barsabas and Silas were sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch.
Only Paul made decisions without consultation.
The church elders acted alone without the apostles.
No representatives were sent; letters were mailed anonymously.
questions.correctAnswer: Chosen men including Judas Barsabas and Silas were sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:22-27 records the sending of chosen men alongside Paul and Barnabas, illustrating shared leadership and accountability.

questions.question: True or False: Acts 15 encourages believers to follow Jewish customs strictly in order to maintain fellowship with the church.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 15 clarifies that Gentiles are not required to follow all Jewish customs such as circumcision but should abstain from specific immoral practices, highlighting freedom in Christ.

questions.question: How can Acts 15 guide a believer who is discouraged by persecution or trials in ministry?
options: Paul and Barnabas continued teaching and confirming churches despite opposition.
Believers should quit ministry when facing trials.
Only apostles face persecution, not regular believers.
Trials indicate God’s disfavor.
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas continued teaching and confirming churches despite opposition.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:35 and 15:41 show Paul and Barnabas persevering in ministry through various regions, encouraging steadfastness in trials.

questions.question: Based on Acts 15, what practical advice would you give to someone struggling with church conflict?
options: Seek peaceful resolution and continue serving the Lord even if separation occurs.
Avoid church altogether to prevent conflict.
Always insist on your way regardless of others.
Stop ministry work until all disagreements are resolved.
questions.correctAnswer: Seek peaceful resolution and continue serving the Lord even if separation occurs.
questions.explanation: Acts 15:39-40 shows Paul and Barnabas separating due to disagreement but both continuing ministry, teaching perseverance and respect despite conflict.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 15.

questions.question: What was the primary issue debated that caused Paul and Barnabas to go to Jerusalem according to Acts 15?
options: Whether Gentile believers needed to be circumcised according to the Law of Moses
Whether Gentiles should be baptized
Whether Gentiles could eat meat sacrificed to idols
Whether Gentiles should observe the Sabbath
questions.correctAnswer: Whether Gentile believers needed to be circumcised according to the Law of Moses
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1 explicitly states that certain men from Judea taught that unless Gentiles were circumcised according to Moses, they could not be saved, which was the central issue prompting the council.

questions.question: How did Peter argue that God showed acceptance of the Gentiles without circumcision?
options: God gave them the Holy Ghost just as He did to the Jewish believers
God made them perform sacrifices
God had them follow the dietary laws strictly
God made them observe the Sabbath only
questions.correctAnswer: God gave them the Holy Ghost just as He did to the Jewish believers
questions.explanation: In Acts 15:8, Peter stated that God bore witness by giving the Holy Spirit to the Gentiles as He did to the Jews, showing acceptance without imposing circumcision.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: James quoted the prophets to support inclusion of Gentiles, saying, 'After this I will return, and will build again the ______ of David, which is fallen down.'
options: tabernacle
temple
altar
wall
questions.correctAnswer: tabernacle
questions.explanation: James in Acts 15:16 quotes prophetic scripture referring to rebuilding the 'tabernacle of David,' symbolizing restoration and inclusion of Gentiles.

questions.question: What four things did the apostles instruct Gentile believers to abstain from in their letter?
options: Pollutions of idols, fornication, meat strangled, and blood
Sabbath work, circumcision, idol worship, and fasting
Unclean animals, pagan festivals, circumcision, and blood
Fornication, fasting, circumcision, and idol worship
questions.correctAnswer: Pollutions of idols, fornication, meat strangled, and blood
questions.explanation: Acts 15:20 and 15:29 specify these four prohibitions as necessary for Gentiles to abstain from, to maintain fellowship without burdening them with the full Mosaic Law.

questions.question: True or False: The apostles and elders agreed to impose the full Mosaic Law on Gentile converts.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 15:28 shows that it pleased the Holy Ghost and the apostles to lay no greater burden than necessary on the Gentiles, explicitly rejecting the full Mosaic Law.

questions.question: Who were sent with Paul and Barnabas to deliver the letter to the Gentiles in Antioch?
options: Judas called Barsabas and Silas
Peter and John
James and Andrew
Philip and Timothy
questions.correctAnswer: Judas called Barsabas and Silas
questions.explanation: Acts 15:22 mentions Judas surnamed Barsabas and Silas as chosen men sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch to deliver the letter.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Gentile believers upon reading the letter from the apostles and elders?
options: They rejoiced for the consolation
They rejected it
They were confused and doubtful
They demanded further clarification
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoiced for the consolation
questions.explanation: Acts 15:31 records that the Gentile believers rejoiced upon reading the letter, finding consolation in the apostles' decision.

questions.question: Which Old Testament figure is referenced in Acts 15 as having preachers in every city reading his teachings on the Sabbath?
options: Moses
David
Elijah
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Moses
questions.explanation: Acts 15:21 notes that Moses has preachers in every city reading his teachings in synagogues on the Sabbath, affirming the continued influence of Mosaic Law.

questions.question: What significant conflict arose between Paul and Barnabas after the council, leading to their separation?
options: Whether to take John Mark with them on their journey
Whether to circumcise Gentiles
Whether to impose dietary restrictions
Whether to visit Jerusalem again
questions.correctAnswer: Whether to take John Mark with them on their journey
questions.explanation: Acts 15:37-39 describe a sharp contention between Paul and Barnabas regarding taking John Mark, resulting in their separation.

questions.question: What was the role of Silas after the dispute between Paul and Barnabas?
options: He accompanied Paul on his journey and was recommended by the brethren
He stayed in Jerusalem as an elder
He returned to Antioch alone
He left the church
questions.correctAnswer: He accompanied Paul on his journey and was recommended by the brethren
questions.explanation: Acts 15:40 states that Paul chose Silas and was commended by the brethren to God’s grace as they traveled together.

questions.question: In the cultural context of Acts 15, why was imposing circumcision on Gentiles considered a 'yoke' that neither the fathers nor believers could bear?
options: Because it represented a burdensome legalistic requirement that was difficult to uphold
Because it was a pagan ritual
Because it conflicted with Roman law
Because it was expensive and time-consuming
questions.correctAnswer: Because it represented a burdensome legalistic requirement that was difficult to uphold
questions.explanation: Peter uses the metaphor of a yoke in Acts 15:10 to describe the heavy and difficult burden of Mosaic legalism, especially circumcision, which even the Jewish ancestors struggled to bear.

questions.question: How does the rebuilding of the 'tabernacle of David' in Acts 15:16 serve as a typological foreshadowing in the New Testament context?
options: It symbolizes the restoration of God's kingdom including Gentiles
It predicts the physical rebuilding of the Jerusalem temple
It refers to David's literal tent being restored
It points to the destruction of pagan temples
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the restoration of God's kingdom including Gentiles
questions.explanation: James’ quote in Acts 15:16-17 uses the imagery of the tabernacle of David to symbolize a renewed kingdom where Gentiles are included, fulfilling Old Testament prophecy in a new covenant context.

questions.question: Which theme is emphasized throughout Acts 15 regarding the inclusion of Gentiles in the early church?
options: Salvation by grace apart from the Law
Strict adherence to Mosaic Law
Exclusive salvation for Jews
Observance of Jewish festivals
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation by grace apart from the Law
questions.explanation: Acts 15:11 highlights that both Jews and Gentiles are saved through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, emphasizing salvation by grace rather than Law observance.

questions.question: True or False: Judea men taught that circumcision was necessary for salvation, causing dispute among early believers.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1 confirms that certain men from Judea taught circumcision was necessary for salvation, which sparked debate.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in the council's letter to the Gentiles, balancing prohibition and grace?
options: Chiasm
Hyperbole
Parable
Alliteration
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: The letter in Acts 15:28-29 uses a chiastic structure emphasizing no greater burden than necessary while listing prohibitions, balancing law and grace.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the initial teaching brought by certain men from Judea that caused significant controversy among the brethren?
options: That Gentiles must be circumcised according to Moses to be saved
That Gentiles must abstain from eating meat
That Gentiles must be baptized twice
That Gentiles must observe the Sabbath strictly
questions.correctAnswer: That Gentiles must be circumcised according to Moses to be saved
questions.explanation: Acts 15:1 states these men taught that unless one was circumcised after the manner of Moses, they could not be saved. This teaching was challenged as it conflicted with the doctrine of salvation by grace (Ephesians 2:8-9; Galatians 5:6; Romans 4:9-12; Philippians 3:3).

questions.question: Who led the delegation to Jerusalem to discuss the question of circumcision and the Law of Moses?
options: Paul and Barnabas
Peter and John
James and Silas
Judas Barsabas and Silas
questions.correctAnswer: Paul and Barnabas
questions.explanation: Acts 15:2 records that Paul and Barnabas, along with certain others, were sent to Jerusalem to consult the apostles and elders about this dispute, highlighting the early church's process of resolving doctrinal issues (Galatians 2:1; Acts 11:30; 1 Corinthians 9:6; 2 Corinthians 11:28).

questions.question: What evidence did Peter give to support that Gentiles received salvation apart from circumcision?
options: God gave them the Holy Spirit just as He did to the Jewish believers
They attended synagogue regularly
They followed the Law of Moses strictly
They observed all Jewish festivals
questions.correctAnswer: God gave them the Holy Spirit just as He did to the Jewish believers
questions.explanation: In Acts 15:8, Peter argues that God, who knows hearts, bore witness by giving the Holy Spirit to Gentiles just as He did to Jewish believers, affirming salvation by grace and faith rather than works of the law (Romans 8:9; Galatians 3:2; John 3:5; Ephesians 1:13).

questions.question: What was James' ruling regarding the Gentile believers and the Law of Moses?
options: Do not trouble Gentiles but write to abstain from certain practices
Require full circumcision and observance of the Law
Force Gentiles to observe the Sabbath
Exclude Gentiles from the church
questions.correctAnswer: Do not trouble Gentiles but write to abstain from certain practices
questions.explanation: Acts 15:19-20 shows James advising not to trouble those turning to God from among the Gentiles, but to write that they abstain from pollutions of idols, fornication, things strangled, and blood, emphasizing unity and minimal requirements for fellowship (Leviticus 17:10-14; Deuteronomy 14:3-21; 1 Corinthians 8:1-13; Romans 14:1-23).

questions.question: According to the letter sent to Gentile believers, what does the Holy Spirit and the apostles impose as necessary burdens?
options: Abstain from meats offered to idols, blood, things strangled, and fornication
Circumcision and keeping the Law of Moses
Observing the Sabbath and Jewish festivals
Tithing and ritual washings
questions.correctAnswer: Abstain from meats offered to idols, blood, things strangled, and fornication
questions.explanation: Acts 15:28-29 explains the Holy Spirit and apostles laid no greater burden than these necessary things, reflecting concern for holiness and unity without imposing the full Mosaic Law, consistent with Old Testament purity laws and New Testament ethical imperatives (Leviticus 17-18; 1 Corinthians 10:25-33; Galatians 5:19-21; 1 Thessalonians 4:3).

questions.question: What role did Judas Barsabas and Silas play in delivering the decision of the Jerusalem council to Antioch?
options: They were chosen messengers and prophets who confirmed the brethren
They opposed Paul and Barnabas
They refused to travel to Antioch
They insisted on circumcision for Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: They were chosen messengers and prophets who confirmed the brethren
questions.explanation: Acts 15:22, 32 records Judas Barsabas and Silas were sent with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch and that they were prophets who exhorted and confirmed the brethren, highlighting the role of prophetic ministry in early church governance (1 Corinthians 14:3-4; Ephesians 4:11-13; Acts 13:1-3; 1 Thessalonians 5:19-21).

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Gentile believers upon reading the letter from the apostles and elders?
options: They rejoiced for the consolation
They rejected the letter
They were confused and disputed
They requested further instructions
questions.correctAnswer: They rejoiced for the consolation
questions.explanation: Acts 15:31 highlights that upon reading the letter, the Gentile believers rejoiced for the consolation, showing relief and encouragement, consistent with New Testament themes of peace and assurance through the gospel (Romans 15:13; Philippians 4:7; 2 Corinthians 7:6; John 16:33).

questions.question: What caused the sharp contention between Paul and Barnabas after their return to Antioch?
options: Disagreement over taking John Mark with them on their journey
Dispute over whether to circumcise Gentiles
Conflict about who should lead the mission
Differing views on observing Jewish festivals
questions.correctAnswer: Disagreement over taking John Mark with them on their journey
questions.explanation: Acts 15:37-39 records that Paul did not think it good to take John Mark because he had left them earlier, leading to a sharp contention and separation, illustrating human struggles in ministry partnerships (2 Timothy 4:11; Colossians 4:10; Philemon 1:24; 2 Timothy 1:16-18).

questions.question: What theological reason did Peter give for not imposing the Mosaic yoke on Gentile believers?
options: Because neither their ancestors nor they could bear the yoke
Because the Law of Moses was abolished
Because Gentiles were inferior to Jews
Because the Law was only for priests
questions.correctAnswer: Because neither their ancestors nor they could bear the yoke
questions.explanation: Acts 15:10 states Peter's argument that imposing the Mosaic yoke on the disciples is tempting God because neither their fathers nor they were able to bear it, indicating the Law's demanding nature and the sufficiency of salvation by grace (Galatians 3:10-14; Matthew 11:28-30; Romans 7:7-25; Hebrews 8:6-13).

questions.question: Which Old Testament prophet's words did James quote to support the inclusion of Gentiles in God's people?
options: Amos
Isaiah
Jeremiah
Ezekiel
questions.correctAnswer: Amos
questions.explanation: Acts 15:15-17 quotes Amos 9:11-12 about God rebuilding the fallen tabernacle of David and including Gentiles, affirming God's plan of salvation for all nations, consistent with Isaiah 49:6 and Psalm 22:27-28 (Amos 9:11-12; Isaiah 42:6; Jeremiah 31:31-34; Ezekiel 37:24-28).

questions.question: According to the chapter, what indicates that God's works have been known since the beginning of the world?
options: God's works are known from the beginning of the world
God's works started only after Christ's resurrection
God works only among the Jews
God's works are hidden from humanity
questions.correctAnswer: God's works are known from the beginning of the world
questions.explanation: Acts 15:18 states that all God's works have been known from the beginning of the world, emphasizing God's sovereign eternal plan, consistent with Psalm 90:2, Isaiah 46:9-10, and Romans 8:28-30 (Psalm 90:2; Isaiah 46:9-10; Romans 8:28; Ephesians 1:4).

questions.question: What was the church's response when Paul and Barnabas declared what God had done among the Gentiles?
options: Great joy to all the brethren
Outrage and rejection
Confusion and debate
Silence and fear
questions.correctAnswer: Great joy to all the brethren
questions.explanation: Acts 15:3 shows that as Paul and Barnabas declared the conversion of Gentiles, it caused great joy to all the brethren, illustrating the inclusive nature of the gospel and the work of the Spirit bringing unity and gladness (Luke 15:7; Romans 15:13; Philippians 4:4; 1 Thessalonians 1:6).

questions.question: What was the main reason for sending Judas Barsabas and Silas along with Paul and Barnabas to Antioch?
options: To deliver the letter and confirm the brethren by word of mouth
To impose circumcision on Gentile believers
To collect financial offerings
To establish new synagogues
questions.correctAnswer: To deliver the letter and confirm the brethren by word of mouth
questions.explanation: Acts 15:27 states Judas and Silas were sent to verbally confirm the letter's contents, reinforcing apostolic teaching and encouraging the Gentile believers, consistent with the early church's emphasis on oral and written apostolic authority (2 Corinthians 8:23; Acts 13:2; 1 Thessalonians 5:12-13; Galatians 2:9).

questions.question: What does the chapter teach about salvation through grace according to Peter’s speech?
options: Salvation is through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ for all, Jew and Gentile alike
Salvation requires strict adherence to the Mosaic Law
Only Jews can be saved
Salvation depends on ritual purity
questions.correctAnswer: Salvation is through the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ for all, Jew and Gentile alike
questions.explanation: Acts 15:11 explicitly states belief in salvation by grace through Jesus Christ for both Jews and Gentiles, affirming core Christian doctrine of justification by faith apart from works of the law (Ephesians 2:8-9; Romans 3:28; Galatians 2:16; Titus 3:5).

questions.question: What does the chapter reveal about the role of the Holy Spirit in church decisions?
options: The Holy Spirit guides and approves the decisions of the apostles and elders
The Holy Spirit is silent in church matters
Decisions are made only by majority vote
The Holy Spirit only speaks through Peter
questions.correctAnswer: The Holy Spirit guides and approves the decisions of the apostles and elders
questions.explanation: Acts 15:28 indicates the decision was made because it seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to the apostles, demonstrating the Spirit’s active role in guiding the early church’s doctrinal decisions, consistent with John 16:13; Romans 8:14; 1 Corinthians 2:10-13; and Ephesians 4:30.
